hints_html:
Make a sketch of the sphere and the paraboloid to find the region of integration.

According to the figure in Hint 1, the region of integration is bounded from below by the paraboloid \(\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2\) and from above by the sphere \(\displaystyle x^2+y^2+z^2 = 6\)

Switch to cylindrical coordinates and calculate the intersection of the paraboloid and the sphere to find the upper integration boundary for the radius.

According to the figure in Hint 1, the region of integration is bounded
from below by the paraboloid $\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2$ and from above by

hints_raw:
Make a sketch of the sphere and the paraboloid to find the region of integration.

[[File:Math200Apr12Q9.jpg|400px|Sketch of sphere and paraboloid]]
According to the figure in Hint 1, the region of integration is bounded from below by the paraboloid <math>\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2</math> and from above by the sphere <math>\displaystyle x^2+y^2+z^2 = 6</math>
Switch to cylindrical coordinates and calculate the intersection of the paraboloid and the sphere to find the upper integration boundary for the radius.
sols_html:
The region of integration is bounded from above by \(\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2\) and from below by \(\displaystyle x^2+y^2+z^2 = 6\).

The intersection of the paraboloid and the sphere is found by substituting the first equation into the second, and solving for z

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x^2 +y^2+z^2 = z + z^2 = 6,\end{aligned}\]

hence \(\displaystyle z_{1,2} = 2, -3\). Since we see on the sketch from Hint 1, that the two surfaces intersect at a positive \(\displaystyle z\) value, the intersection is at \(\displaystyle z=2\).

We switch to cylindrical coordinates and express the \(\displaystyle z\)-variable in dependence of the radius \(\displaystyle r = \sqrt{x^2+y^2}\).

  • The largest value of \(\displaystyle r\) in the region of integration is where the sphere and the paraboloid intersect, namely at \(\displaystyle r = \sqrt{z} = \sqrt{2}\). The integration limits for the radius are \(\displaystyle 0\leq r\leq \sqrt{2}\).

  • The variable \(\displaystyle z\) is bounded from below by \(\displaystyle z=r^2\) and from above by \(\displaystyle r^2+z^2 = 6\), that is, \(\displaystyle z = \sqrt{6-r^2}\). So the integration boundaries are \(\displaystyle r^2 \leq z\leq \sqrt{6-r^2}\).

  • The angle \(\displaystyle \phi\) does not depend on \(\displaystyle z\) or \(\displaystyle r\) and completes the whole circle \(\displaystyle 0\leq \phi\leq 2\pi\).

  • The integrand function in cylindrical coordinates is \(\displaystyle x^2+y^2 = r^2\)

Hence, the integral to calculate is

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}\int_0^{2\pi}r^2r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}z\text{d}r &=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}2\pi r^3\;\text{d}z\text{d}r \\ &=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(\sqrt{6-r^2} - r^2)\;\text{d}r \\ &=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(6-r^2)^{\frac12}\;\text{d}r - \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^5\;\text{d}r\end{aligned}\]

Now we perform integration by parts in the first integral, where we consider \(\displaystyle u = 2\pi r^2\) and \(\displaystyle dv = r(6-r^2)^{\frac12}\). Then \(\displaystyle du = 4\pi r\) and \(\displaystyle v = -\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\). Overall we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} &= \left[ -2\pi r^2\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}} + \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}4\pi r\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\;\text{d}r - \left[2\pi\frac{r^6}{6}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}}\\ &= -2\pi 2\frac13(6-2)^{\frac32} + 0 - \left[4\pi\frac{1}{15}(6-r^2)^\frac52\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}} - 2\pi\sqrt{2}^6\frac16 + 0\\ &= -\frac{32}3\pi - \frac{4}{15}\pi 32 + \frac{4}{15}\pi 36\sqrt{6} - \frac83\pi\\ &= \frac{\pi}{15}(144\sqrt{6} - 328) \approx 5.18\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The region of integration is bounded from above by
$\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2$ and from below by
$\displaystyle x^2+y^2+z^2 = 6$.

The intersection of the paraboloid and the sphere is found by
substituting the first equation into the second, and solving for
\emph{z}\begin{align*}
\displaystyle x^2 +y^2+z^2 = z + z^2 = 6,
\end{align*} hence
$\displaystyle z_{1,2} = 2, -3$. Since we see on the sketch from Hint 1,
that the two surfaces intersect at a positive $\displaystyle z$ value,
the intersection is at $\displaystyle z=2$.

We switch to cylindrical coordinates and express the
$\displaystyle z$-variable in dependence of the radius
$\displaystyle r = \sqrt{x^2+y^2}$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The largest value of $\displaystyle r$ in the region of integration is
  where the sphere and the paraboloid intersect, namely at
  $\displaystyle r = \sqrt{z} = \sqrt{2}$. The integration limits for
  the radius are $\displaystyle 0\leq r\leq \sqrt{2}$.
\item
  The variable $\displaystyle z$ is bounded from below by
  $\displaystyle z=r^2$ and from above by $\displaystyle r^2+z^2 = 6$,
  that is, $\displaystyle z = \sqrt{6-r^2}$. So the integration
  boundaries are $\displaystyle r^2 \leq z\leq \sqrt{6-r^2}$.
\item
  The angle $\displaystyle \phi$ does not depend on $\displaystyle z$ or
  $\displaystyle r$ and completes the whole circle
  $\displaystyle 0\leq \phi\leq 2\pi$.
\item
  The integrand function in cylindrical coordinates is
  $\displaystyle x^2+y^2 = r^2$
\end{itemize}

Hence, the integral to calculate is

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}\int_0^{2\pi}r^2r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}z\text{d}r 
&=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}2\pi r^3\;\text{d}z\text{d}r \\
&=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(\sqrt{6-r^2} - r^2)\;\text{d}r \\
&=\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(6-r^2)^{\frac12}\;\text{d}r - \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^5\;\text{d}r
\end{align*}

Now we perform integration by parts in the first integral, where we
consider $\displaystyle u = 2\pi r^2$ and
$\displaystyle dv = r(6-r^2)^{\frac12}$. Then
$\displaystyle du = 4\pi r$ and
$\displaystyle v = -\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}$. Overall we obtain

\begin{align*}
&= \left[ -2\pi r^2\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}} + \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}4\pi r\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\;\text{d}r - \left[2\pi\frac{r^6}{6}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}}\\
&= -2\pi 2\frac13(6-2)^{\frac32}  + 0 - \left[4\pi\frac{1}{15}(6-r^2)^\frac52\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}} - 2\pi\sqrt{2}^6\frac16 + 0\\
&= -\frac{32}3\pi - \frac{4}{15}\pi 32 + \frac{4}{15}\pi 36\sqrt{6} - \frac83\pi\\
&= \frac{\pi}{15}(144\sqrt{6} - 328) \approx 5.18
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The region of integration is bounded from above by <math>\displaystyle z=x^2+y^2</math> and from below by <math>\displaystyle x^2+y^2+z^2 = 6</math>.


The intersection of the paraboloid and the sphere is found by substituting the first equation into the second, and solving for ''z'':  <math>\displaystyle x^2 +y^2+z^2 = z + z^2 = 6</math>, hence <math>\displaystyle z_{1,2} = 2, -3</math>. Since we see on the sketch from Hint 1, that the two surfaces intersect at a positive <math>\displaystyle z</math> value, the intersection is at <math>\displaystyle z=2</math>.


We switch to cylindrical coordinates and express the <math>\displaystyle z</math>-variable in dependence of the radius <math>\displaystyle r = \sqrt{x^2+y^2}</math>.
* The largest value of <math>\displaystyle r</math> in the region of integration is where the sphere and the paraboloid intersect, namely at <math>\displaystyle r = \sqrt{z} = \sqrt{2}</math>. The integration limits for the radius are <math>\displaystyle 0\leq r\leq \sqrt{2}</math>.
* The variable <math>\displaystyle z</math> is bounded from below by <math>\displaystyle z=r^2</math> and from above by <math>\displaystyle r^2+z^2 = 6</math>, that is, <math>\displaystyle z = \sqrt{6-r^2}</math>. So the integration boundaries are <math>\displaystyle r^2 \leq z\leq \sqrt{6-r^2} </math>.
* The angle <math>\displaystyle \phi </math> does not depend on <math>\displaystyle z</math> or <math>\displaystyle r</math> and completes the whole circle <math>\displaystyle 0\leq \phi\leq 2\pi</math>.
* The integrand function in cylindrical coordinates is <math>\displaystyle x^2+y^2 = r^2</math> 


Hence, the integral to calculate is

<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}\int_0^{2\pi}r^2r\;\text{d}\phi\text{d}z\text{d}r 
=&\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}\int_{r^2}^{\sqrt{6-r^2}}2\pi r^3\;\text{d}z\text{d}r \\
=&\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(\sqrt{6-r^2} - r^2)\;\text{d}r \\
=&\int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^3(6-r^2)^{\frac12}\;\text{d}r - \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}2\pi r^5\;\text{d}r
\end{align}</math>

Now we perform integration by parts in the first integral, where we consider <math>\displaystyle u = 2\pi r^2</math> and <math>\displaystyle dv = r(6-r^2)^{\frac12}</math>. Then <math>\displaystyle du = 4\pi r</math> and <math>\displaystyle v = -\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}</math>. Overall we obtain

<math>\displaystyle\begin{align}
=& \left[ -2\pi r^2\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}} + \int_0^{\sqrt{2}}4\pi r\frac13(6-r^2)^{\frac32}\;\text{d}r - \left[2\pi\frac{r^6}{6}\right]_0^{\sqrt{2}}\\
=& -2\pi 2\frac13(6-2)^{\frac32}  + 0 - \left[4\pi\frac{1}{15}(6-r^2)^\frac52\right]_0^\sqrt{2} - 2\pi\sqrt{2}^6\frac16 + 0\\
=& -\frac{32}3\pi - \frac{4}{15}\pi 32 + \frac{4}{15}\pi 36\sqrt{6} - \frac83\pi\\
=& \frac{\pi}{15}(144\sqrt{6} - 328) \approx 5.18
\end{align}</math>
statement_html:
Let E be the smaller of the two solid regions bounded by the surfaces

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}z=x^2+y^2\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}x^2+y^2+z^2=6.\end{aligned}\]

Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \iiint\limits_{E}(x^2+y^2)\textrm{d}V.\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
Let E be the smaller of the two solid regions bounded by the surfaces

:<math>
\displaystyle{}z=x^2+y^2
</math>

and

:<math>
\displaystyle{}x^2+y^2+z^2=6.
</math>

Evaluate

:<math>
\iiint\limits_{E}(x^2+y^2)\textrm{d}V.
</math>
